name: Marguerite

topics.topic_text: I want to know more about you.
topics.response_text: Why, I'm just folk.  What more is there?

topics.topic_text: How bad is Orange Fever?
topics.response_text: Nothing you can catch, if that's what you were wondering. Marsh folk catch it all the time. Lucky my family has a special still pot for tonic-makin'.

topics.topic_text: What do you think of Point Lookout?
topics.response_text: Things aren't wonderful, but I reckon it's hard all around.

topics.topic_text: Did you build that still yourself?
topics.response_text: That old thing's been in my family for years and years.

topics.topic_text: Why did you fake being sick?
topics.response_text: Here I thought you were a quick one.

topics.topic_text: Let's change the subject.
topics.response_text: I thought you'd never ask.

topics.topic_text: I'm sorry, I guess I just haven't heard of that illness. Maybe I can help.
topics.response_text: I reckon you can, at that.  I just need some help brewing up a little tonic.

topics.topic_text: You're faking. We both know it. So let's just cut to the chase.
topics.response_text: Well, I - oh, fine. Maybe you're no hogsfool, but I reckon we both come out better if you can help me cook up some tonic.

topics.topic_text: Orange Fever? That sounds bad. Can I help?
topics.response_text: Awful malady, I do swear. There's a tonic for it, but I reckon I'm not well enough to make it myself.

topics.topic_text: I've treated enough illnesses to know there's no such thing as Orange Fever.
topics.response_text: Now that is just an awfully rude thing to say, sweetie.

topics.topic_text: Yeah? I've got the mauve plague. So let's just try not to cough on each other.
topics.response_text: Well sweetie, even if you ain't got sympathy in your heart, I think you need the 'ol tonic as bad as me, even if'n you don't know it yet.

topics.topic_text: You're sick? What's the matter?
topics.response_text: Reckon it's the Orange Fever.  I do feel light in my head...

topics.topic_text: Oh boy, here we go...
topics.response_text: Shouldn't tease somebody come down with Orange Fever, sweetie.

topics.topic_text: Actually, I already took care of it.
topics.response_text: Well, I'll be. Here, let me give you something for your trouble.

topics.topic_text: I'll get it working like new, but I want 200 caps.
topics.response_text: I reckon you've got a deal, sweetie, but I'd better notice a difference in the tonic.

topics.topic_text: I can fix it up. Let's call it 100 caps of work?
topics.response_text: I reckon I can scrape that together. Go ahead and do what you can for it.

topics.topic_text: Yeah, I can fix it. No charge.
topics.response_text: Aren't you a smart one?  Sweeter tonic's better for both of us, after all.

topics.topic_text: Your still could stand to be fixed up.
topics.response_text: Could it, now?  I suppose you'd know how to see to that, wouldn't you?

topics.topic_text: Has the tonic finished brewing?
topics.response_text: Should be ready in a matter of hours. Check back soon.

topics.topic_text: Batteries? For extra "kick"?
topics.response_text: You best keep this one to yourself, sweetie.   The family tonic gets real kick from our secret ingredient.  We just need a lil' bit of battery acid.

topics.topic_text: We need Punga Fruit?
topics.response_text: Punga fruit and lots of it. The stuff those loonies make at the church is best. Ten of those will do, but might cost you.

topics.topic_text: Here, take ten of these refined Punga Fruit.
topics.response_text: Sweet and ripe, too. These will do just fine.

topics.topic_text: Twenty wild Punga Fruit, just for you.
topics.response_text: Little scrawny, but they'll do. Thank you, sweetie.

topics.topic_text: You mentioned yeast?
topics.response_text: Well, we'll need yeast. You can find it about anywhere, but there's a big stash on the boardwalk. Three sacks is enough.

topics.topic_text: What now?
topics.response_text: We got everything. Now we wait while it brews. Three days should do the trick.

topics.topic_text: Let's talk about this tonic.
topics.response_text: Secret family technique, been so for generations.

topics.topic_text: Okay, I'll bite. What do we need?
topics.response_text: This and that. Let me know when you want to work out the details.

topics.topic_text: Not interested right now. Sorry.
topics.response_text: That's a righteous shame, but the offer stands. You just say the word, hon.

topics.topic_text: What is this stuff, anyway?
topics.response_text: Tell you what - have a bit. This is left over from an old batch, but should be a swig or two there. More'n enough to loosen you up, I wager!

topics.topic_text: Does this tonic really cure anything at all?
topics.response_text: Oh, just about whatever ails you, sweetie!  A real cure-all.  Say, I don't reckon you're the dry type, is you?  Oh, nevermind.

topics.topic_text: Why exactly should I help you, again?
topics.response_text: Well, I don't rightly expect you to help me out of goodness, though I welcome you to prove me wrong, sweetie.
Good things, sweetie. Tonic's brewed and bottled.  Here's your pay and cut of the batch. Enjoy it!

topics.topic_text: SpeechChallengeFailure
topics.response_text: *cough* No, sweetie, this is the Orange Fever, and unless I get somebody to help me whip up some tonic, I'm as good as dust for the grave.

description:
Marguerite is a 45 year-old Marshfolk Female.

A tough and resourceful woman of the marsh, Marguerite has lived in Point Lookout her entire life. Despite not sharing the exact physical appearance of the local swampfolk, she has fully embraced their way of life and culture. She runs a small moonshining operation from her shack, continuing the family business that dates back to the Prohibition era.

Marguerite's Personality: Marguerite is cunning and opportunistic, willing to use deception to get what she wants. She's fiercely independent and proud of her family's moonshining heritage. Despite her tough exterior, she values trust and will reward those who prove themselves worthy with her famous moonshine.

Marguerite's Backstory: Marguerite is a direct descendant of a family of moonshiners who operated in the Point Lookout area during the Prohibition era. Her ancestors produced and sold their homemade liquor when alcohol was banned, and they continued the practice after the Great War. Marguerite was born and raised in the marshes, learning the family trade from her parents. Over the years, she has become an expert moonshiner, known for her potent and distinctive brews.
